INVESTIGATED AVIATION TESTS
Dr. Dunlap, as Major in Sanitary Corps,
worked out Psychological Problems
of Aviation—Large Staff at
Mineola Laboratory.

Dr. Knight Dunlap, in a recent
address to the Scientific Association of Hopkins, told of his work
for the Medical Research Board,
as a Major in the Sanitary Corps.
Dr. Dunlap had charge of the experiments conducted to determine
how aviators are affected by lack
of oxygen, and also of those conducted to see if the nystagmus
test, in which the subject is revolved in a chair, was really valuable. This test was found by
both the Americans and British
to be useless.
The psychological problems of
aviation were investigated under
the direction of the Medical Research Board, a branch of the
Air Medical Service. Dr. Dunlap began work at the Bureau of
Mines Laboratory in October,
1917, with two assistants and
continued in charge of the Psychological Department until August 30, 1918, on which date he
was transferred from the Mineola
Laboratory. During this period
his staff grew to about twentyfive officers and seventeen men.
The first work required of the
board was the construction and
standardization of a test for determining, if possible, the individual flier's ability to endure the
partial asphyxiation incident to
high altitudes. Dr. Dunlap entered this work with the understanding that, as soon as such a
test was completed, he should
have opportunity to investigate
other more important psycho.
physical problems, because he
was unwilling to disorganize his
university work merely for the
development of such a test.
Starting -on an entirely unknown sea, Dr. Dunlap and his
small, but highly efficient, staff
were able to get results in a relatively short time. After trying a
wide range of standard psychophysical tests, and some devised
after the usual patterns, with
puzzling results, the actual primary effects of asphyxia were hit
upon and tests were devised to fit.
Some important observations
were made on psychological causing accidents (although no research was done) from accidents
in the low pressure chamber and
from study of air accidents, it

stimulation of air pressure inward on the ear drum, may (aside
from any lesion of the membrane
produce mental incompetence, and
apparent unconsciousness. Such
stimulation occurs at times when
exceptionally rapid descents are

asphyxiation work makes 'obvious,
from the lack of oxygen, but
these cases present features different from the above, the descent
improving the situation since it
increases the oxygen supply.
The Psychological Department
conducted experiments and secured data bearing on the nystagmus test which was supposed to
test a man's ability to keep his
equilibrium. The first attack
upon the problem consisted in
observations upon circus performers, vaudeville *stunters and dancers, in the effort to determine the
nystagmus-reactions of these individuals of demonstrated high
ability in equilibrium. Five men
were each given turning, at the
"standard" rate of ten turns in
twenty seconds, first in one direction, then after a brief resting
period, in the opposite direction,
and so on, for approximately half
an hour.
All the men had durations far
below the official lower limits
for passing candidates and one
showed no nystagmus at all.
New and much superior tests
are being devised to take the
place of the nystagmus test.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAR. 18, 1919

In accordance with custom,
there will be no issue of the
NEWS-LETTER on the week following the examination.
Honor In Examinations.

The honor system now in operation at Hopkins was instituted
in the fall of 1913. Several undergraduates, who had been attracted from other universities to
our campus, together with several
of our own native genius, felt
Hopkins should have an honor
system. Accordingly, they started a discussion, which culminated
in conferences between faculty
and istudent representatives, and,
finally, in the drafting of a set
of resolutions, which were approved by the faculty, and later
at a mass meeting by the undergraduates. This, in a word, is
the story of the birth of our honor
system.
Prior to that time there was
no definite system. The conduct
of examinations was left entirely
to the discretion .of the instructors, who came and went at will,
putting their trust in the honor
of Hopkins men. In fact, any
other course of procedure little
occurred to either faculty or. examiners. We are proud that the
evil system of policing was not
in vogue. At many large uni-

versities the students were under
the watchful eye of proctors, who
paraded the examination rooms
—and, indeed, such a system is
still in wide use.
The need for such odious supervision was never felt at Hopkins;
however, for the good of all concerned, the present more definite
and uniform, though perhaps less
idealistic, system was adopted.
It 'is gratifying that it is not
encumbered with a set of objecMonable iron-bound rules. The
signing of the pledge printed on
the exam book, be it understood
by all new-comers, is in no wise
obligatory; the Student Council
merely recommends it to the students. It is easily conceivable
that some may be offended by
having the question put them;
and, indeed, in the days when the
scheme was first tried, many refused to sign. It would be condemnable if Hopkins men were to
be coerced, either by Student
Council or instructor, into obeying such rules. It has, indeed,
been argued that a man dishonest enough to cheat in an examination would not hesitate to sign
an untrue statement; yet there
may be some weak, misguided
individuals, upon whom the
knowledge that they are expected
to state that they have neither
given nor received help may
have a salutory effect.
The
raison d'etre pledge is protection
against, and aid for such weaklings, and an appreciation of the
confidence the faculty has reposed
in us; it is not at all a reflection
upon the integrity of Hopkins
men. This point should be clearly
understood by any who object to
signing.
The Student Council has the
right—and it should have—to
eject from the University any
transgressor of the laws of honor
in examination, for he is not a
fit associate for college men.
Merely as a matter of caution—
that our honor system might be
fully understood — the explanatory slips were distributed last
week. It is regrettable that the
great bulk of students must be
imposed upon by such explanations and such a pledge—and, indeed, by any definite system
whatever; but it must be realized that they are an aid to
weaker brothers, from whom only
a Salomon's House is free.
Sweet Is Pleasure After Pain.

We, for the most part, are not
shirkers, but men trying to make
the most of university life. It is
in accordance with this motive
alone that the sugestion is made
that exams be followed by a period of respite—a custom maintained by most of the larger colleges and universities.
Before 1916 when the two-term
year was inaugurated at Hopkins, each set of examinations
was succeeded by a vacation—
Christmas, Easter and summer.

Spurred by this anticipation, the
student put his very best into
preparation for the test. Then,
too, it. is noticeable that when
there is no recess after examinations, the subsequent week is invariably marked by a minimum
of work. There is a distinct letdown from the real or imagined
strain; hence, the majority derive little benefit from the week
of instruction. The same principle applies that has led employers—or at least our worthy political economists—to believe that a
workman can actually accomplish
more in an eight or ten-hour day
than in one of ten or twelve.
Hereafter, the authors of the
year's schedule can offer no excuse of wartime pressure, which
may be advanced this year. We
hope that, in the future, whether
the two-term year holds or not,
the University authorities, with
their wonted benevolence, will
make provision for post-exam
recreation.

Favors Chapel Service.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Hopkins is lacking in a
tradition which holds such a vital
part in the curriculum of most
of the universities that it is the
first thing thought of in recollections of the Alma Mater. I speak
of the morning chapel service.
There is not room to discuss the
manner of holding such chapels
in the various universities, but I
Will state a few common characteristics.
The chapel service is usually of
fifteen to twenty minutes in
length four days of the week, and
one hour on Friday. The service
is conducted by the Dean or
President who opens with a reading from the Bible. Several
sacred and college songs follow,
and then either the presiding
officer or an outside speaker gives
a ten-minute talk. The exercise
is concluded with the reading of
announcements of all student and
collegiate activities whicli merit
the attention of the undergraduate body for that day. On Friday a prominent speaker, is secured to give a vocational or
popular talk.
The opening part of the exercise gives a moment of thought
to the sacred to which no one
has been entirely foreign, at
least before the entrance to the
University. The talk refreshes
the interest of the students; and
the announcements are the students themselves, so as to speak,
the best way to get spirit and
co-operation in all activities.
Although Hopkins is not a denominational institute, is it necessary or wise to avoid having a
chapel, which is such a fundamental part of student life in
A. J.
other Universities?

Doing Social Service Work.

Another piece of work which
the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. is doing
outside of the student activities
is the social service work in the
various recreation and community centers of the city. These
centers, located in the poorer districts of the city, furnish healthful recreation for the younger
children after school hours by instruction in games of basketball,
baseball and soccer, as well as
vocational training such as woodwork, basket weaving, manual
training and photography.
The leaders and instructors are
members of the various universities, colleges and clubs in town.
Hopkins has several men at the.
different community houses, who
give from one to two evenings a
week for this social service work.
This activity holds special interest for those who are taking
courses in social science. Anyone who may be interested in
work of this kind may obtain
further information from H. Merserean or E. P. Hayes.
American University Union Active.

The interests of the American
University Union in Europe have
been recently merged with those
of the "Maison des Etudants" in
Paris. During the war the Union
has maintained an American center and University Club in Paris
where between 25,000 and 30,000
former students of American universities, now engaged in military
service in Europe, have registered. The Municipal Council of
Paris has presented to the
"Maison des Etudants," a valuable piece of ground as a site for
a building to serve as a center
for American students in Paris.
The association of these two
organizations will probably bring
about a closer union of American
and French intellectual and academic interests.
Dr. Goodnow is a charter member of "Maison des Etudants."

NEW BOOK BY PROF. HOLLANDER
United States Treasury Certificates of
ndebtedness Discussed—Author
Points out some Defects in
America's War Borrowing.

Professor Jacob H. Hollander's
latest work "War Borrowing, a
Study of Treasury Certificates
of Indebtedness of the United
States," is to be issued by the
MacMillan Company, New York,
on March 18.
Professor Hollander has undertaken to examine the part which
public credit has played in our
national defence during the period up to the signing of the armistice, with particular reference
to the use of anticipatory borrowing through Treasury certificates of indebtedness.
A preliminary feature of the
publication is the review of earlier instances in our history in
which recourse has been had to
negotiable short term debt obligation. Professor Hollander thereafter describes in detail the
thirty-one issues of certificates of
indebtedness emitted by the
Treasury in connection with our
war financing.
This book is of especial interest
to all economists and students of
political economy, because in the
succeeding chapters the direct
fiscal results of the Treasury's
policy in this connection are analyzed, and its collateral effects
upon the business world, through
the money-market, and upon social well-being, through the price
level, are traced.
The conclusion of the text is
also of importance. Professor
Hollander maintains that past
experience, theoretical analysis,
and present evidence all point to
the conclusion that our war borrowing, sound and admirable in
the main, has been marred here
and there by serious error, injuring us now, and certain if unamended to work to our disadvantage hereafter.
In his final chapter he presents
in a most convincing manner certain positive and practical suggestions with respect to the
future.

INVESTIGATED AVIATION TESTS
Dr. Dunlap, as Major in Sanitary Corps,
worked out Psychological Problems
of Aviation—Large Staff at
Mineola Laboratory.

Dr. Knight Dunlap, in a recent
address to the Scientific Association of Hopkins, told of his work
for the Medical Research Board,
as a Major in the Sanitary Corps.
Dr. Dunlap had charge of the experiments conducted to determine
how aviators are affected by lack
of oxygen, and also of those conducted to see if the nystagmus
test, in which the subject is revolved in a chair, was really valuable. This test was found by
both the Americans and British
to be useless.
The psychological problems of
aviation were investigated under
the direction of the Medical Research Board, a branch of the
Air Medical Service. Dr. Dunlap began work at the Bureau of
Mines Laboratory in October,
1917, with two assistants and
continued in charge of the Psychological Department until August 30, 1918, on which date he
was transferred from the Mineola
Laboratory. During this period
his staff grew to about twentyfive officers and seventeen men.
The first work required of the
board was the construction and
standardization of a test for determining, if possible, the individual flier's ability to endure the
partial asphyxiation incident to
high altitudes. Dr. Dunlap entered this work with the understanding that, as soon as such a
test was completed, he should
have opportunity to investigate
other more important psycho.
physical problems, because he
was unwilling to disorganize his
university work merely for the
development of such a test.
Starting -on an entirely unknown sea, Dr. Dunlap and his
small, but highly efficient, staff
were able to get results in a relatively short time. After trying a
wide range of standard psychophysical tests, and some devised
after the usual patterns, with
puzzling results, the actual primary effects of asphyxia were hit
upon and tests were devised to fit.
Some important observations
were made on psychological causing accidents (although no research was done) from accidents

stimulation of air pressure inward on the ear drum, may (aside
from any lesion of the membrane
produce mental incompetence, and
apparent unconsciousness. Such
stimulation occurs at times when
exceptionally rapid descents are

The Psychological Department
conducted experiments and secured data bearing on the nystagmus test which was supposed to
test a man's ability to keep his
equilibrium. The first attack
upon the problem consisted in
observations upon circus performers, vaudeville *stunters and dancers, in the effort to determine the
nystagmus-reactions of these individuals of demonstrated high
ability in equilibrium. Five men
were each given turning, at the
"standard" rate of ten turns in
twenty seconds, first in one direction, then after a brief resting
period, in the opposite direction,
and so on, for approximately half
an hour.
All the men had durations far
below the official lower limits
for passing candidates and one
showed no nystagmus at all.
New and much superior tests
are being devised to take the
place of the nystagmus test.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

MAR. 18, 1919

In accordance with custom,
there will be no issue of the
NEWS-LETTER on the week following the examination.
Honor In Examinations.

The honor system now in operation at Hopkins was instituted
in the fall of 1913. Several undergraduates, who had been attracted from other universities to
our campus, together with several
of our own native genius, felt
Hopkins should have an honor
system. Accordingly, they started a discussion, which culminated
in conferences between faculty
and istudent representatives, and,
finally, in the drafting of a set
of resolutions, which were approved by the faculty, and later
at a mass meeting by the undergraduates. This, in a word, is
the story of the birth of our honor
system.
Prior to that time there was
no definite system. The conduct
of examinations was left entirely
to the discretion .of the instructors, who came and went at will,
putting their trust in the honor
of Hopkins men. In fact, any
other course of procedure little
occurred to either faculty or. examiners. We are proud that the
evil system of policing was not
in vogue. At many large uni-

versities the students were under
the watchful eye of proctors, who
paraded the examination rooms
—and, indeed, such a system is
still in wide use.
The need for such odious supervision was never felt at Hopkins;
however, for the good of all concerned, the present more definite
and uniform, though perhaps less
idealistic, system was adopted.
It 'is gratifying that it is not
encumbered with a set of objecMonable iron-bound rules. The
signing of the pledge printed on
the exam book, be it understood
by all new-comers, is in no wise
obligatory; the Student Council
merely recommends it to the students. It is easily conceivable
that some may be offended by
having the question put them;
and, indeed, in the days when the
scheme was first tried, many refused to sign. It would be condemnable if Hopkins men were to
be coerced, either by Student
Council or instructor, into obeying such rules. It has, indeed,
been argued that a man dishonest enough to cheat in an examination would not hesitate to sign
an untrue statement; yet there
may be some weak, misguided
individuals, upon whom the
knowledge that they are expected
to state that they have neither
given nor received help may
have a salutory effect.
The
raison d'etre pledge is protection
against, and aid for such weaklings, and an appreciation of the
confidence the faculty has reposed
in us; it is not at all a reflection
upon the integrity of Hopkins
men. This point should be clearly
understood by any who object to
signing.
The Student Council has the
right—and it should have—to
eject from the University any
transgressor of the laws of honor
in examination, for he is not a
fit associate for college men.
Merely as a matter of caution—
that our honor system might be
fully understood — the explanatory slips were distributed last
week. It is regrettable that the
great bulk of students must be
imposed upon by such explanations and such a pledge—and, indeed, by any definite system
whatever; but it must be realized that they are an aid to
weaker brothers, from whom only
a Salomon's House is free.
Sweet Is Pleasure After Pain.

We, for the most part, are not
shirkers, but men trying to make
the most of university life. It is
in accordance with this motive
alone that the sugestion is made
that exams be followed by a period of respite—a custom maintained by most of the larger colleges and universities.
Before 1916 when the two-term
year was inaugurated at Hopkins, each set of examinations
was succeeded by a vacation—
Christmas, Easter and summer.

Spurred by this anticipation, the
student put his very best into
preparation for the test. Then,
too, it. is noticeable that when
there is no recess after examinations, the subsequent week is invariably marked by a minimum
of work. There is a distinct letdown from the real or imagined
strain; hence, the majority derive little benefit from the week
of instruction. The same principle applies that has led employers—or at least our worthy political economists—to believe that a
workman can actually accomplish
more in an eight or ten-hour day
than in one of ten or twelve.
Hereafter, the authors of the
year's schedule can offer no excuse of wartime pressure, which
may be advanced this year. We
hope that, in the future, whether
the two-term year holds or not,
the University authorities, with
their wonted benevolence, will
make provision for post-exam
recreation.

Favors Chapel Service.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Hopkins is lacking in a
tradition which holds such a vital
part in the curriculum of most
of the universities that it is the
first thing thought of in recollections of the Alma Mater. I speak
of the morning chapel service.
There is not room to discuss the
manner of holding such chapels
in the various universities, but I
Will state a few common characteristics.
The chapel service is usually of
fifteen to twenty minutes in
length four days of the week, and
one hour on Friday. The service
is conducted by the Dean or
President who opens with a reading from the Bible. Several
sacred and college songs follow,
and then either the presiding
officer or an outside speaker gives
a ten-minute talk. The exercise
is concluded with the reading of
announcements of all student and
collegiate activities whicli merit
the attention of the undergraduate body for that day. On Friday a prominent speaker, is secured to give a vocational or
popular talk.
The opening part of the exercise gives a moment of thought
to the sacred to which no one
has been entirely foreign, at
least before the entrance to the
University. The talk refreshes
the interest of the students; and
the announcements are the students themselves, so as to speak,
the best way to get spirit and
co-operation in all activities.
Although Hopkins is not a denominational institute, is it necessary or wise to avoid having a
chapel, which is such a fundamental part of student life in
A. J.
other Universities?

Doing Social Service Work.

Another piece of work which
the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. is doing
outside of the student activities
is the social service work in the
various recreation and community centers of the city. These
centers, located in the poorer districts of the city, furnish healthful recreation for the younger
children after school hours by instruction in games of basketball,
baseball and soccer, as well as
vocational training such as woodwork, basket weaving, manual
training and photography.
The leaders and instructors are
members of the various universities, colleges and clubs in town.
Hopkins has several men at the.
different community houses, who
give from one to two evenings a
week for this social service work.
This activity holds special interest for those who are taking
courses in social science. Anyone who may be interested in
work of this kind may obtain
further information from H. Merserean or E. P. Hayes.
American University Union Active.

The interests of the American
University Union in Europe have
been recently merged with those
of the "Maison des Etudants" in
Paris. During the war the Union
has maintained an American center and University Club in Paris
where between 25,000 and 30,000
former students of American universities, now engaged in military
service in Europe, have registered. The Municipal Council of
Paris has presented to the
"Maison des Etudants," a valuable piece of ground as a site for
a building to serve as a center
for American students in Paris.
The association of these two
organizations will probably bring
about a closer union of American
and French intellectual and academic interests.
Dr. Goodnow is a charter member of "Maison des Etudants."

NEW BOOK BY PROF. HOLLANDER
United States Treasury Certificates of
ndebtedness Discussed—Author
Points out some Defects in
America's War Borrowing.

Professor Jacob H. Hollander's
latest work "War Borrowing, a
Study of Treasury Certificates
of Indebtedness of the United
States," is to be issued by the
MacMillan Company, New York,
on March 18.
Professor Hollander has undertaken to examine the part which
public credit has played in our
national defence during the period up to the signing of the armistice, with particular reference
to the use of anticipatory borrowing through Treasury certificates of indebtedness.
A preliminary feature of the
publication is the review of earlier instances in our history in
which recourse has been had to
negotiable short term debt obligation. Professor Hollander thereafter describes in detail the
thirty-one issues of certificates of
indebtedness emitted by the
Treasury in connection with our
war financing.
This book is of especial interest
to all economists and students of
political economy, because in the
succeeding chapters the direct
fiscal results of the Treasury's
policy in this connection are analyzed, and its collateral effects
upon the business world, through
the money-market, and upon social well-being, through the price
level, are traced.
The conclusion of the text is
also of importance. Professor
Hollander maintains that past
experience, theoretical analysis,
and present evidence all point to
the conclusion that our war borrowing, sound and admirable in
the main, has been marred here
and there by serious error, injuring us now, and certain if unamended to work to our disadvantage hereafter.
In his final chapter he presents
in a most convincing manner certain positive and practical suggestions with respect to the
future.

A few days before the closing
of enlistments in the R. 0. T. C.
on March 15, a delegation of seniors from the Omecron Delta

interest in all college activities
and is strongly in favor of the
R. O. T. C.

underclassmen had not "come
across" in the proper spirit.

due to the belief that R. 0. T. C.
work would interfere with athletics. This, of course, is absolutely not the case. The two
work hand in hand. Excuses,
therefore, are readily granted
members participating in athletics. Moreover, Baxley pointed

June.

unit.

told the freshmen that the delegation represents the spirit of
the upper-classmen. Also, that
its action was entirely voluntary
they, in no wise, represented Captain Guild. Not only, said Morley, did an R. 0. T. C. member
receive wide experience among
men drawn from all parts of the
country at the summer camps,
but the general educational value
of the course was great. It will
be, in fact, in no ,way inferior to
the value received from other

favor of the R. 0. T. C.
